work.p: This manuscript is a draft of the following lines of the 1860 poem "Proto-Leaf" (eventually titled "Starting from Paumanok"): "Behold! the body includes and is the meaning, the main concernâ€”and includes and is the Soul; / Whoever you are! how superb and how divine is your body, or any part of it" (1860, p. 17) and "How can the real body ever die, and be buried?" (1860, p. 16).

titleStmt.title: How can there be immortality
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: These lines bear a strong resemblance to lines in the (eventual) thirteenth section of "Starting from Paumanok," which was first published in 1860 as "Proto-Leaf."

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: How can there be immortality
bibl.orgName: Papers of Walt Whitman (MSS 3829), Clifton Waller Barrett Library of American Literature, Albert H. Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
A series of draft lines on the back of this manuscript leaf relate to the manuscript poem "Pictures."

body.l:
All is Divine is the body—person—it is all—
it is the soul also

How else can thenre be immortality,
except through mortality?

How can the ultimate realities of visible things
be visible?

del.l: How else except in the though all things tend

body.l: How can the real body ever die and be
